And also, thank you,
everyone, for being here. It's quite a group. And thanks so much
for being here.

And yeah, today I would like
to talk about my PhD work, evaluating and
designing computing

systems for the future of work. So I'd like to start this
talk by posing a question

on everyone, what computing
technology would improve human collaboration
and decision-making?

Well, someone from
120 years ago started to think about this
particular question.

English writer Arthur Mee wrote
the following back in 1898. "If, as it is said to be not
unlikely in the near future,

the principle of sight is
applied to the telephone as well as that of sound, earth
will be in truth a paradise,

and this will lose its
enchantment by being abolished altogether." As you might have
guessed out, he

was talking about something that
is similar to what we have known as video conferencing today.

And indeed, 120
years later, we now, indeed, have this kind of
video conference technologies.

We have Zoom, Microsoft
Teams, and we also have messaging apps like Slack
to help us even getting closer

at workplace. We also have sophisticated
computing devices

like AR and VR, which give
us a different experience at the workplace
and more recently, have this wave of AI from
ChatGPT, GitHub Copilot,

to Microsoft Copilot, which
drastically changed our way we get things done at work,
improved our productivity,

and sometimes, even
our creativity. So the question really
becomes, given all the advances

in technologies
these days, have we already developed the ideal
workplace technologies?

Are we living in a
paradise, as suggested by Arthur Mee 120 years ago?

Well, the landscape is
really vague and unclear.

There have been mixed views in
current workplace technologies. On one hand, there have
been positive sentiments.

For example, in this
New York Times article, someone is saying, "Distance
matters much less now.

Because of the
technology these days, we're actually inching closer
and closer to replicating

the office." And we have articles like
this with title, "Why is Zoom
suddenly everywhere? It's easy and fun to use."

On the other side, also about
Zoom and another article in the New York Times
has the title like this,

"Why Zoom Is Terrible." And I would say based on
the usefulness of computing

technologies, they're not
unique to workplace scenario. They also apply
to other scenarios

as well, such as education,
relationship, and health where we have seen lots
of discussions and debates

on whether certain technologies
have been helping or hurting that particular scenario.

So the thing that I've
become really interested in is that rather than arguing
back and forth with each other

on whether technology
is helping or hurting, how do we navigate
such disagreements and make progress on
computing technologies.

I would argue it's perhaps time
to study computing technologies as a science of the artificial.

And this particular
term is proposed by Simon, who is a pioneer
in artificial intelligence

and in many other fields such
as decision-making theory. And this particular book,
which was written back in 1969,

is themed around how
artificial phenomenon ought to be categorized. And Simon discussed
whether such phenomenon

belong within the
domain of science in a similar way as natural
subjects such as physics.

Specifically, Simon
wrote the following, "natural science is knowledge
about natural objects

and phenomena. We asked whether there
cannot also be "artificial" science knowledge about
artificial objects

and phenomena." And in this book, Simon
gave the high-level vision

about some important
factors that would contribute towards a
science of the artificial.

So they are empirical evidence,
technical methods, and design.

And specifically, Simon
wrote the following about the empirical evidence. The contingency of
artificial phenomenon

has always created doubts as
to whether they fall properly within the compass of science.

The general problem is to show
how empirical propositions can be made at all about systems.

In terms of technical
methods, throughout the book, Simon emphasized the importance
of modeling simulation

as well as other
technical approach. And finally, in terms
of design, Simon wrote,

"it's important to study
not only how things are, but also how things
ought to be."

And my PhD research has
been largely influenced by Simon's vision. And I've been following
this particular idea

and try to make it more concrete
with specific technologies and applications.

And during my PhD,
I've been fascinated by a number of questions on
the empirical evidence side.

I'm interested in
things like how can we leverage increasingly
available large-scale data to study machine behavior and
human behavior of computing

platforms. In terms of technical
methods, I've been interested in asking
and answering things

like how can we better model
sense and predict machine behavior and human behavior.

And finally, in terms of
design, I'm interested in things like how can we
design applications

that align with our
needs and values with powerful
computing technologies.

And with that vision
in mind during my PhD, I've conducted a number
of cross-disciplinary collaborations.

I have worked with researchers
from human-computer interaction, natural language
processing, as well as

scholars from management,
science, and sociology. And beyond academia,
I got the fortune

to work with a number of big
tech companies, startups, and nonprofit organizations.

While I have diverse interests
in many different applications, my core contributions
during my PhD

has been on this very notion
of workplace technologies. And I feel very
fortunate during my PhD,

I've been contributing a number
of works with these three dimensions on empirical
evidence, technical methods,

and design, and
published a number of papers in different
venues ranging from HCI to social science.

And today, I'd really
like to focus on my work during my PhD on
workplace technologies

and how I have been leveraging
this kind of Simon's vision to study workplace technologies.

And specifically, I'd like
to give the overview of three projects that I did.

On the empirical evidence side,
I'd like to talk about my work where I've been mining
millions of online meetings,

emails, and files trying to make
sense of people's remote meeting experience during remote work.

And in terms of
technical methods, I'd like to talk about my work
using AI to help us better

understand team collaboration. And specifically, in
this particular work, I've been thinking about how
we can leverage AI, data,

and natural language processing
to try to classify and even predict ahead of
time the team outcome

and in this particular
case, team viability. And finally, in
terms of design, I'd

like to talk about
our recent work on how we have been using
generative AI and specifically

large language
model to re-envision the way researchers get
things done and get feedback.

And in this work,
I'd like to talk about how we have been using
large language model to design a tool to build scientific
feedback tool for researchers

and the evaluation results
through large-scale empirical evidence. And with that, I would like to
dive into specific projects.

So the very first project
is on large scale analysis of multitasking behavior
during remote meetings, which

I got the fortune to collaborate
with a number of Microsoft Research researchers.

So essentially saying that
we are interested here in this particular work is on
this notion and this experience

that we have a lot during
the pandemic period where we have been
talking about things like Zoom fatigue, meeting
engagement, and productivity

[INAUDIBLE] those days. And those discussions have been
both over academic publications

as well as over public outlets. And in this particular
work, our goal

is to achieve a systematic
understanding of remote meeting multitasking behavior.

Why remote meeting? I don't think I need
to spend much time here because we have experienced
that remote work has

become an essential mode of
work ever since the pandemic. And central to remote
work are remote meetings

through video
conferencing tools which help team members stay
connected, collaborate, and function as an organization
despite physical distance.

And multitasking
behavior is some behavior social scientists have
studied for a long time which

refers to performing more
than one task in parallel or in rapid succession. And prior work has
shown multitasking

is closely linked to one's
productivity and well-being.

And multitasking behavior,
as we have experienced, is an important
meeting experience.

And many of us have that
particular multitasking behavior during remote
meetings where we have been checking emails or
getting other things done

during the meetings. Despite its ubiquity, there is
a lack of understanding when,

how, and why people engage
in multitasking behavior on the remote meetings.

And beyond that,
on the other side, while multitasking is a concept
that people have explored

for a long time
in social science, many of the studies on
multitasking over computing

platforms, they are relatively
limited in coverage where people have been studying like 20-ish
or 30-ish people and to get some

conclusions over that kind
of observational study. So the other contributions
that we want to achieve here

is, can we get a large
scale analysis and a better understanding of multitasking
behavior during remote meetings.

And we want to achieve
that through some sort of mixed-methods design. So here are a number
of research questions

that we seek to address here. First of all, how
much multitasking is happening during
remote meetings.

Secondly, what
factors associated with multitasking
during remote meetings. And thirdly, what do
people do when multitasking

during remote meetings. And finally, what
are the consequences of multitasking during
remote meetings.

And as I mentioned, in
this particular work, we adopt the
mixed-methods approach. There are two core
parts of this study.

First of all, there's
large-scale data analysis and regression
analysis where we have

been using passively-collected
data to measure and to reflect objective patterns as well.

And on the other
side, to complement this particular
telemetry data analysis, we also run a diary study to
provide qualitative evidence

with the goal to capturing
the nuanced experiences and motivations behind
multitasking behavior.

So let's talk about the
telemetry data first. So in this particular
study, we collected

meeting-related actions from
Microsoft Teams, email usage data from Microsoft
Outlook, file edits data

from SharePoint and OneDrive. And we collected four separate
week-long snapshots of the data

during and before the pandemic
of all Microsoft US employees.

And with this rich
data set, we first derived a number of
meeting characteristics,

including meeting duration,
meeting size, meeting types, hour of the day, day of the
week as the characteristics

to represent the
particular meetings. And after we've
derived those features,

we joined the three
different data sources by unique user identifier,
which in this case

is the anonymized
Microsoft user account. And for each meeting
user pair, we

label it as email
multitasking if the user was found to have at
least one active email

action during the meeting. Otherwise, we assign a
nonmultitasking label. And similarly, we labeled
file multitasking.

And after that, we ran a
conditional logistic regression to understand the relationships
between multitasking and meeting

characteristics. And the second method
that we used here is diary study so
as to complement

that quantitative evidence. We have this particular
survey question, what have you noticed
about multitasking

in your recent online meetings
with a list of subprompts. And we ran this diary
study between mid-April

and mid-August 2020, which
is around the similar time period where we collect
the telemetry data.

And in total, we've
collected 819 responses.

around 30% of the meetings
involved email multitasking and around 25% of meetings
involved file multitasking.

And we found that
more multitasking may be a possible result of
work rhythm adaptation and that ease of turning
off video and audio

may encourage more multitasking. And the second
conclusion that we get

is perhaps the most
interesting part of the study, where we have been looking at
a number of intrinsic meeting

characteristics
that are associated with meeting multitasking. We find more
multitasking happening

in large, long, morning,
and recurring meetings, as well as meetings with
lower relevance or engagement.

And to dive in a
little bit here, we find that people are
more likely to multitask in larger meetings,
where the odds of email

multitasking in meetings
with over 10 attendees are 2.16 times the odds of
meetings with 2 attendees.

People are more
likely to multitask during longer meetings with
the odds of email multitasking in meetings over 80 minutes
at 6.21 times the odds of 0

to 20 minutes meetings. These two findings are intuitive
and align with our experience.

I think what is really
cool about this data set is that we can also uncover
some patterns that

are not that obvious. For example, we find here people
are more likely to multitask

in morning meetings. The odds of email multitasking
in morning meetings are 1.86 times the odds
of after our baseline,

and it's also higher
than afternoon meetings. And we get some kind
of qualitative evidence

from the diary study. And this particular
participant is saying, I will try to glimpse
that email more

if a meeting is the first thing
I do for work in the morning. So that's schedule related.

We also hear from
people that people are more likely to multitask
in recurring meetings.

Through the telemetry
data analysis, we find that the odds of email
multitasking in recurring meetings are 1.59 times the odds
of one-off or ad-hoc meetings.

And here are some explanation
from another participant where the person says he
or she has to be

in a meeting that doesn't
really have anything to do with the person. But since the
meeting is recurring,

the person has to be there. So the person just
ended up multitasking.

So given all of this,
we should really ask ourselves could the
meeting and especially those recurring meetings
be an email instead?

We also found a number extrinsic
meeting characteristics that were associated
with multitasking.

We found people
multitask during meetings to catch up on other work. While people multitask
during meetings

due to some external
distractions such as software notification sound. And people multitask during
meetings for anxiety relief.

And in terms of what do
people do when multitasking. Some of them are work related,
such as email multitasking

and file multitasking,
which also verifies why we chose this particular
data for the telemetry data

analysis. And of course, there are
also nonwork-related things such as browsing social media
or doing household chores.

And finally, in terms of the
consequences of multitasking, there are both positive
and negative sides.

Where prior literature talked
about the negative consequences of multitasking behavior a
lot, such as loss of attention,

engagement fatigue, and a sense
of disrespect, which we also hear from people here,
what is interesting

here is that we also hear from
people that they're actually finding some positive
experience with multitasking,

where people have been
talking about how multitasking helps boost productivity.

So taking all of this
together, this particular work, we provide large-scale
empirical evidence

on multitasking behavior
and how switching over multiple computing platforms.

And through our findings,
we could come up with a number of best practice
guidelines for how to run

effective remote meetings. For example, from
our study, it might

be advisable to avoid important
meetings in the morning, reduce the number of
unnecessary meetings, show the meeting durations
and insert breaks,

encourage active
contribution, and allow space for positive multitasking
so that people may have

better remote work experience. And from a more human-computer
interaction tool-building

perspective, in this
particular work, we discussed things
such as Focus Mode during remote meetings
so that people

could concentrate on the meeting
rather than being distracted by software notification sound. And we also discussed
features in future apps

where people could
decide which meetings or which part of the meetings
they could attend to.

And since the publication
of this particular work, I feel very fortunate that
this work not only got

some kind of
attention in academia, but it also got taken
up in the public space.

We have been reported
by various news media, including Wired,
TED, and Forbes.

And practitioners are
actually using some insights from our particular work.

For example, Slack
have the blog posts on how to run
effective remote work.

And I also noticed
that some institutes, like this one from
Berkeley HR departments,

they're actually using our
particular research results as training materials
for people on how

to better run remote meetings. And finally, this
specific approach

of deriving empirical
evidence using telemetry data to understand meeting
effectiveness actually

has been built into
some sorts of features in Microsoft product.

And with that, I would like to
conclude my first work, which I think would be a good
representative of my line

of work, How we have been
deriving novel insights using data sets that haven't been
really used for research

purposes before and tried
to use that to derive empirical evidence to better
understand how we work.

And the second study
I want to present here is on the technical
methods part,

where we have been using
AI and natural language processing trying to get
a better sense of team

collaboration experience. And this particular
work is conducted here

at Stanford with
Michael and a group of really talented undergrad
and master's students.

In this particular work, we are
interested in also something that is very familiar to us,
which is team collaboration.

So in our team collaboration
experience, I'm sure many of you have this experience that
some team collaboration,

it ends up very successful,
whereas some other team collaboration, it
eventually falls apart

where we do not really want to
work together with the same team ever again. So I started to wonder,
are there any patterns

behind team collaboration? How quickly can we get to
know that a particular team is

going to end poorly? And that's the goal of
this particular work,

where we aim to classify
and predict team viability.

Team viability is
also a concept that has been studied in prior work
by social scientists, which

refers to team capacity
for future success. It captures the team's interest
in continuing to work together.

And it reflects team members'
satisfaction towards each other. And prior work has shown
low team viability could

lead to a team falling apart.  I'm definitely not
the first person

to study this notion
of team collaboration. Team collaboration has
been a central topic

in many social
science literatures, from management to sociology. Yet one limitation,
I would argue,

for many of the prior
work is that they focus on team
performance as a metric of successful collaboration,
which definitely

makes a lot of sense. Yet there are other sides
of the team collaboration, such as team Viability
High-performing teams,

they could also
have low viability. Even if the team--
say, a product team gets things done in
time or even delivers

the product in a
perfect way, there could be conflicts in the team
where the team members do not

really want to work
together with each other. So I would say team viability
is another side of the story.

Yet we lack enough
understanding of the mechanism behind team viability.

Through this present work,
we introduced a mechanism for classifying high versus low
viability teams using only team

chat interactions. And here are a number
of research questions we seeked to address here.

First of all, can
we differentiate high versus low liability
teams by analyzing team chat

interactions? Secondly, what behaviors
are most strongly associated with high
versus low liability teams?

And thirdly, how much
time must the team interact before we can make
accurate classifications of team

viability? And to answer those
research questions, in this particular
work, we collected

data sets where we have complete
chat history of over 660

conflict tasks over 10 minutes. And by the end of each
task, each team member,

they were asked to complete a
14-item viability instrument on a 5-point Likert scale, which
is some instrument that has been

used by prior social scientists. For example, they
are asked things

like whether they agree
with the statements, the members of this team could
work for a long time together.

After they complete
this particular survey, we summed each collaborator's
14 viability measures

into one single individual
score ranging from 14 to 70 and calculated the mean of
all of the individual score

to determine a team
viability score, which has the distribution like this.

And so the thing that
we are interested here in this particular
work is can we classify high versus
low viability teams.

And to operationalize that,
we divided all teams into two groups, either they have high
viability or low viability

based on their viability score. And we said that the cutoff
viability score as a varying decision threshold
so we can answer

different sorts of questions. For example, can we classify
the most viable teams?

And to operationalize,
we make it as classified the top
10 percentile of teams

by mean viability. We also have tasks like classify
the top 50 percentile of teams

by mean viability,
as well as tasks that classify the
top 90% of teams by means of viability,
which in other words,

is that can we classify
the least viable teams.

So this particular task
turned into some kind of binary classification model.

And in this particular
work, we specifically chose a number of
explainable machine learning classifiers
so that we could better

understand what are some
of the behavior traits that are associated
with team viability rather than just
throwing everything

into the black box model. And specifically, we report
results from logistic regression

here. But we also ran penalized
logistic regression or Lasso regression here to understand
the behavior traits that are

associated with team viability. So here are the
specific interaction

features that have been used
in this particular work. Broadly speaking, there
are two categories,

computationally-derived
features as well as human-labeled features. In terms of
computationally-derived

features, those are the things
that we could automatically derive through algorithms
such as work pattern

features like message
counts or turn taking, as well as linguistic features
which we can use off the shelf

NLP toolbox to get things
like word traces measured through new categories
or sentiment analysis.

On the other side, we have
human-labeled features so as to better speak to
the rich literature on team

collaboration. And here for
human-labeled features, we have another group of
Amazon Mechanical Turk workers

who manually read and code the
transcripts on some dimensions where prior work has
shown to be associated

with team collaboration
experience, such as social loafing. And using those features, we
did the classification task.

And here are the results. First of all, in
our study, we found

that team viability can be
classified with higher accuracy. We find that classifying top 50%
percentile viable teams yields

0.76 AUC score and classifying
top 10% of variable teams

is even a better performance,
which is 0.93 AUC. And this is something that
is really interesting here.

The fact that it is easier to
classify the most viable teams suggests that the
most viable teams

may share very similar
behavioral patterns that have been captured by
our specific approach.

Whereas teams with
lower viability, they may be falling apart
for different reasons that

haven't been captured by our
specific methods that well. And the other thing that
I want to highlight here

is on the right-hand figure. So there are three curves here. They are blue,
green, and orange.

And they represent the
classification results using different feature sets. And the blue curve represents
the classification results

using only
computationally-derived features. Orange curve represents results
using human-labeled features.

And the green curve represents
combining all the features that we have. And the y-axis here
represents the performance

of the classification. And as you can see
here, the blue curve tends to be the highest,
which in other words

means the
computationally-derived features, using them only, we
can get the best performance

in many occasions to classify
this notion of team viability, which is interesting
in the sense

that when we think about
downstream application, we could actually use this
kind of automatic features

that could be derived from
algorithms to understand team collaboration.

And it can be
performing even better than human-labeled features
inspired by prior literature.

And some other
results in this study include, we found a number
of behavioral traits

that are associated
with high viable team. For example, we found active
response and engagement

is an indicator of
high viability teams. Use of exclusive
language such as but,

either, except, and addressing
each other in second person pronoun, they are
significantly and positively

correlated with
higher viability. And to understand why
that might be the case,

here's a particular
example from our study where these three people,
they have been interacting

and they have been using
quite some exclusive language, such as but, either, and except.

And you could perhaps
see that they are really trying to address each other
and having lots of conditions on the things that
they are talking about,

showing that they have
been actively engaging in that particular
collaboration.

And finally, back to
the very first slides where we have the motivations
behind this particular study,

we investigated the
time period that is needed so as to make
accurate prediction of where

the team is going. And using our data
sets, we found that classification
of team viability

is feasible after only 70
seconds of initial interaction, which is the first 12%
of the data that we have.

And it achieves
95% of the accuracy from using the full transcript
when differentiating

the top 10% of the teams. And we see similar patterns
for other viability

splits as well, which all
indicates that there are perhaps enough viability
signals embedded

in the interaction
of team members within a short time span
in the initial interaction.

So to sum this up, in
this particular work, we looked at this notion
of team viability, which

is more on the subjective
experience of the team collaboration. And we found team
viability is driven

by a number of
underlying mechanisms that are common across
different team setups, and task categories, and can be
largely captured and explained

by automatic features that could
be derived from algorithms. And we think about
downstream applications,

this could be an
interesting starting point. Perhaps we could
have an algorithm

to have some kind of early
detection of low viability teams, giving some kind of
recommendations, nudges,

or interventions so
as to improve the team experience before the
team really falls apart.

And of course, I would like
to point out here in this particular work, our data is
limited to online teams working

on 10-minute interaction, which
is not that representative.

In our follow-up
work, we actually have been in collaboration
with a number of partners

like software engineering
teams in the wild and to see whether
such kind of methods

could be applied to more
realistic workforces.

And finally, for this particular
work, we do have a website. And we have a
functioning algorithm

there where you could
upload your own charts and test out whether your
team is viable or not. [LAUGHTER]

So that wraps up
the second study, which is on the technical
methods aspects.

And finally, I would like
to talk about design and how we can leverage state
of the art methods

and to use that
to rethink how we might be working in the future.

In this particular work, I
got the fortune to work with-- to collaborate with
a number of students

here at Stanford, which I
feel super fortunate about, is I'm using large
language model

to provide scientific
feedback for research papers. And the key thing that
we are interested in here

is on scientific feedback. As many of us have experienced,
scientific feedback

is very important
for researchers. It improves research
works by melding insights from multiple people.

And it also lays the
foundation of rigorous research where people use
that as to watch

whether the quality of the
research is good enough or not. And there are multiple channels
of scientific feedback.

And arguably, one of the
most important channel is peer review
feedback, which we will focus in this particular work.

Despite its importance, getting
quality scientific feedback is really challenging,
and especially given

the increasing number
of paper submissions that we have in some fields like
computer science these days.

For example, this
graph shows the number of ICLR submissions over time.

And for those of you who
are not familiar with ICLR, it's just one of the most
important conferences

in computer science
on deep learning. So this particular
conference, 10 years ago,

there are just a few
hundred submissions. But in 2023 we see over 6,000
paper abstract submissions.

So this field has grown a lot. And this is also the case for
many other fields as well.

And the direct impact of
this increasing number of papers in so many
different fields is that we see
overloading reviewers.

And people have been
complaining of the difficulties in securing qualified reviewers
on the editor or chair

size, which has been shown
both over public discussions

over social media
where people have been complaining a lot and also
in research papers as well.

On the other side,
scientific feedback also has implications for
the quality of science.

Where under-resourced
researchers, they may have even
harder times getting timely and quality feedback,
such as people who are junior,

or people who are non-elite
institutes, or researchers from resource-limited
regions, it might be even harder for
them to get quality feedback.

So the thing that we are
really curious about here is, can large
language model, given all its incredible performances
in so many different tasks,

could it provide useful
feedback on research papers? So here's what we did.

First, we prototyped
this particular tool where people could upload
the raw PDF of their papers.

And then the tool will
parse this PDF to get the contents of the paper. And using a prompt, which
we carefully tuned and fed

to GPT-4, this particular tool
could give back the authors

some scientific feedback in a
similar format as a peer review.

And after building and
designing this particular tool, the thing that we are very
interested in is, does it work.

And to operationalize,
here we conducted a mixed-methods
analysis to evaluate

whether scientific feedback
provided by large language model is helpful or not. And specifically, there
are two parts of the study.

Study one is a
retrospective evaluation where we compare what
has been generated by AI versus what has been
generated by humans in the past.

And for the second study, we
have a prospective user study and survey which we HCI
researchers are familiar with,

where we send this particular
tool to actual researchers from over 110 US
institutes focusing

on AI and computational
biology to assess whether they find this
particular tool helpful or not.

So I'll mostly talk about
the retrospective evaluation and briefly talk about the user
study given the time limitation.

So in this retrospective
evaluation, we first curated two
large-scale data sets.

One is from Nature
Family journals, covering over 3,000 papers and
over 8,700 human-written reviews

covering 15 Nature
Family journals. And we have another
data set from ICLR,

the deep learning conference,
with over 1,700 papers and over 6,500 human-written reviews.

So they have different

On the other hand,
ICLR data sets, it focused on one single

accepted and rejected papers.

And the core part of
this particular work is a retrospective
common matching pipeline.

For both the
AI-generated feedback and human-generated
feedback, we first

used GPT-4 to get
a summarization of the key common points
for that particular work.

And after we got the summarized
key point of those points from AI or
human-generated feedback,

we then asked GPT-4 to
evaluate to what extent they are similar to each other.

And based on the
similarity score, we calculated a
coefficient of the matching

to represent to what extent
they overlap with each other.

And this particular
pipeline, we validated using human verification
which proves

to be pretty good performance. And here are the results we
got from this retrospective

evaluation. First of all, we found
large language model feedback significantly overlaps
with human generated feedback.

Around 30% of the
comments raised by GPT-4, it overlaps with comments from
one individual human reviewer.

And to put that into context,
the overlap between one human reviewer and another human
reviewer for the same paper

is also around 30%. In other words, GPT-4,
at a high level,

is giving some feedbacks
like another human reviewer. We find similar patterns
over the ICLR data sets.

And such trends hold
for different subfields. And we also find something
really interesting

here, that the overlap between
GPT-4 and human reviewers is larger for weaker papers.

Where we stratify the results
by ICLR decision outcome, we find for rejected
papers, there

are actually more
overlaps between AI and human, which is
interesting in the sense

that those weaker
or rejected papers, they might also
be the papers that need most feedback from people.

some kind of results on the overlaps
between AI and human.

we conducted a random

mostly produce generic feedback
that applies to many papers. If that's the case, it will

the review and
the paper, then we should expect to see
no change in overlap

if the feedback is generic that

in overlap, indicating that
the large language model feedback is paper specific.

they are more likely to be
